Issues.Title: refactor(ivy): Move instructions back to …µ…µ
Issues.Body:
There is an encoding issue with using delta `Œî`, where the browser will attempt to detect the file encoding if the character set is not explicitly declared on a `<script/>` tag, and Chrome will find the `Œî` character and decide it is window-1252 encoding, which misinterprets the `Œî` character to be some other character that is not a valid JS identifier character

So back to the frog eyes we go.

```
    __
   /…µ…µ\
  ( -- ) - I am ineffable. I am forever.
 _/    \_
/  \  /  \
==  ==  ==
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor(ivy): Move instructions back to …µ…µ" (#30546)

Issues.Title: refactor(ivy): evaluate map-based styling bindings with a new algorithm
Issues.Body:
This is the first refactor PR designed to change how styling bindings
(i.e. `[style]` and `[class]`) behave in Ivy. In addition to the changes
added in f03475cac8bbc79aaf13caf94b099b0c234028bc, this patch adds
functionality for map-based styling bindings such as `[style.prop]`
and `[class.name]` in ivy.

Issues.Title: feat(ivy): in `ngDevMode` use named object literals and arrays for easier debugging/profiling
Issues.Body:
Ivy uses object literals for speed and size. These are very hard to debugging because all types are an array or object literals without any useful hints to the developer. Similarly when profiling memory consumption it is hard to tell which object is which and so it is hard to track down memory pressure. This change enables constructor names for the Ivy dat structures making the code base more approachable.  

Here is an example what the data structure look like now in debugger:
![Screen Shot 2019-05-17 at 9 46 19 AM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/111951/57943710-94929d80-7889-11e9-9a32-1dd9bcf4248e.png)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR " feat(ivy): in `ngDevMode` use named object literals and arrays for easier debugging/profiling" (#30542)

Issues.Title: Context for projected template not working (but present)
Issues.Body:
So I have a component template like this: ```html
``` In the `component.ts` I have: `@ContentChild('row') rowUserTemplate: TemplateRef;` Where I use this component: ``` This is great {{ test }} ``` This gets the *projected* template, and correctly renders it, but it does not render `test`. I looked in the browser console, and I can see in the `projectedView` of the `TemplateRef` (the ContentChild), that the context does exist. Why isn't it doing the interpolation?

# üìö Docs or angular.io bug report

### Description

When following the guide on creating decleration file for imported JS-library you refer to TypeScript documentation. But no information on how to actually import a index.d.ts module file.

**Files**:

Js-file
```
function doSomething(params) {
    console.log("doesSomething ", params)
    }
```

```
declare module "functionsModule"{
    export function doSomething(param: string);
}
```

```
import { Component, OnInit } from '@angular/core';
import {doSomething} from 'functionsModule';

@Component({
  selector: 'app-ownjsfile',
  templateUrl: './ownjsfile.component.html',
  styleUrls: ['./ownjsfile.component.scss']
})
export class OwnjsfileComponent implements OnInit {
  constructor() { }

  ngOnInit() {
    doSomething("Hello World?");
  }
}

Issues.Title: ng xi18n generation for app with multiple components
Issues.Body:
I am trying to generate xlf files for translating an Angular app constructed around several components (each being in a subfolder of the app/src main folder).
When I run ng xi18n to generate xlf translation, only one component is being analyzed and the output only contains translation source for the html of that component. All others seems to be ignored. Am I doing something wrong or is this a general issue with CLI?
Thanks a lot,
Emmanuel

Issues.Body:
Fixes Ivy throwing an error when something is passed in as a `forwardRef` into `@Injectable`'s `useClass` option. The error was being thrown, because we were trying to get the provider factory off of the wrapper function, rather than the value itself.

This PR resolves FW-1335.

Issues.Title: Angular is not suitable choice for enterprise grade systems!
Issues.Body:
This is some sort of rant, but here we go:
after many months experiencing and long consideration and thinking i decided to make following statement: Angular in field in small and middle size company's , i say implementing enterprise heavy solutions in Angular **is not comfortable and very slow**, even writing test in tdd style is complicated  and unstable. 
**I dont want to discourage people using Angular**, but if managers read this github and thinking about Angular thats it , think twice or trice before you switch to Angular , because it may well cost your more then you think or can imagine.
For my clients i would highly recommend to switch to Vue.Js and others lightweight  java script frameworks.

Issues.Title: Contradicting and incorrect Injectable docs
Issues.Body:
# üìö Docs or angular.io bug report

## Description
I wanted to know how Injectable worked and whether or not we are actually required to use it (not that I want to omit it, just as a matter of understanding how things work).

At first, I thought Injectable was always required for any service that's used (either by adding it to the providers or using providedIn, which requires Injectable anyway) in Angular.

However, we noticed that Injectable is only required to be used as a decorator on a service that has dependencies which are being injected into its constructor.

This was easily verified using a Stackblitz: https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-pgkrb5

- If you would omit the @Injectable from `FooService`, it'll show an error: `Can't resolve all parameters for FooService: (?).`. 
- If you would inject BarService (which has no @Injectable) into the AppComponent, everything works fine as well.

However, doing some more testing it turns out we can replace the Injectable decorator with any other decorator, even the HostBinding works: https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-qkngb5

Doing some googling on this quickly showed me I wasn't the first one noticing this, so this is not really something new I guess.

However, in order to fully understand how it worked, I needed to fiddle with Stackblitz, the docs didn't really give me a proper answer. I found some things I wanted to update to be more accurate if anyone else ever would have the same question as I had.

As I don't think the above findings are things that necessarily need to end up in the docs, I thought I would be better of creating an issue first to discuss this further before creating a PR to update the docs.

## A few remarks on snippets from the docs
https://angular.io/api/core/Injectable

> Injector throws an error if it tries to instantiate a class that is not decorated with @Injectable, as shown in the following example.

I think this isn't entirely correct, it's only the case when that service has dependencies which are being injected in its constructor. 

https://angular.io/guide/dependency-injection#services-that-need-other-services

> Notice that the Logger service also has the @Injectable() decorator, even though it might not need its own dependencies. In fact, the @Injectable() decorator is required for all services.

> When Angular creates a class whose constructor has parameters, it looks for type and injection metadata about those parameters so that it can inject the correct service. If Angular can't find that parameter information, it throws an error. Angular can only find the parameter information if the class has a decorator of some kind. The @Injectable() decorator is the standard decorator for service classes.

Both snippets above might be a bit contradicting, the first one mentions it's required for all services. While the second snippet is mentioning the fact that the class' constructor needs to have parameters.

## What I'd propose to change:

https://angular.io/api/core/Injectable:

> Injector throws an error if it tries to instantiate a class that is not decorated with @Injectable and is making use of Dependency Injection (add link to https://angular.io/guide/dependency-injection or https://angular.io/guide/dependency-injection#services-that-need-other-services here), as shown in the following example.

Maybe we can also include an example that shows it doesn't throw in case we omit Injectable and have no Dependency Injection.

https://angular.io/guide/dependency-injection#services-that-need-other-services

> Notice that the Logger service also has the @Injectable() decorator, even though it might not need its own dependencies. Even though it's not required to add Injectable when you're not making use of Dependency Injection, we do encourage adding it as this will make it easier to add dependencies later on.

> When Angular creates a class whose constructor has parameters, it looks for type and injection metadata about those parameters so that it can inject the correct service. If Angular can't find that parameter information, it throws an error. Angular can only find the parameter information if the class has a decorator of some kind. The @Injectable() decorator is the standard decorator for service classes.

Even tho this still isn't 100% correct (as Injectable isn't required, any decorator should do), I think this could be an improvement.

I'm also not aware if Ivy would change anything with regards to this, if this is the case these changes might be obsolete.

# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [x] build - [ ] serve - [x] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Is this a regression? Yes. Sourcemaps in karma/jasmine worked fine up to and including@angular/cli 8.0.0.beta.9, but from beta.10 to current (rc.4 today) sourcemaps no longer work. ### Description Example working output from beta.9: ``` Expected true to be falsy. at UserContext. (src/app/app.component.spec.ts:32:18) ``` Example broken output from beta.10+: ``` Error: Expected true to be falsy. at at UserContext. (src/app/app.component.spec.ts:32:18)` * `ng update --next --all --force` to update to something more recent than 8.0.0.beta.10 * repeat `ng test` and note line numbers no longer help you find your spec in app.component.ts. Issues.Title: ng update fails to remove polyfills leaving broken code behind (8rc 4)
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [ ] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [x] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Is this a regression? Yes, previous ng updates that I have tried worked as expected. ### Description When running `ng update @angular/cli @angular/core --next` the process completes successfully, however the polyfills file has been left broken. It appears to have attempted to remove the core-js imports although failed half way through leaving half a line of code: ```typescript /*************************************************************************************************** * BROWSER POLYFILLS */ k-map'; import 'core-js/es6/set'; /** IE10 and IE11 requires the following for NgClass support on SVG elements */ // import 'classlist.js'; // Run `npm install --save classlist.js`. ``` All imports after the broken line are not removed. This obviously causes the build to fail. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Clone this repo: https://github.com/UXAspects/UXAspects-Seed Perform the update: `ng update @angular/cli @angular/core --next --force` CLI will report success, however the broken code now remains ## üî• Exception or Error No exceptions during update, reports successful update ## üåç Your Environment

Issues.Title: a path configured in tsconfig.json dosen't work in ./server.ts in Angular universal mode
Issues.Body:
I have created an Agular library and puts its path to paths array in tsconfig.json
note that this path refers to 'src' of the library, not 'dist' folder


tsconfig.json:
```
    "paths": {
      "*": ["node_modules/*", "src/types/*"],
      "myLib": ["projects/myLib/src/public-api"],
      "myLib/*": ["projects/myLib/src/lib/*"]
    }
```

server.ts
```
import { example } from "myLib" //cannot resolve myLib, although when I click in this module in my IDE it directly open the correct path i.e public-api.ts file
import { example } from "projects/myLib/src/public-api" //works!
```

Issues.Title: Older CLI projects don't match the tsconfig layout of newer projects
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report

### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are effected by this bug? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: -->
```
- [x] update
```

### Is this a regression?
No

### Description
Older projects (such as https://github.com/GDGTC/devfest/commits/master/src/tsconfig.json) have a single tsconfig file. This was never migrated by our tooling to `tsconfig.app.json` which means that some of our assumptions about these files are incorrect. This breaks things such as the schematics in 8 to take advantage of differential loading.

We should consider detecting these configs and migrating them.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Older CLI projects don't match the tsconfig layout of newer projects" (#14436)

Issues.Title: ng g c with selection of app.module.ts
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request

angular 7+

### Description
Hello, my current app folder looks like the following :
 - app
 - - _app-base
 - - - app.module.ts
 - - - app-routing.module.ts
 - - - app-component
 - - - - app.component.html
 - - - - app.component.sass
 - - - - app.component.ts
 - - _components
 - - - administration (omitting the obvious files)
 - - - session (and many others)
 - - _data
 - - _guards
 - - _helpers (so forth and so on)

The problem i'm encountering is that since my app.module.ts isn't at the root of the app folder, i need to use the --skipImport when using ng g c....which can be annoying and time consuming when creating components, services and other parts.

### Describe the solution you'd like

Is it possible to add a setting to say where the main module of the app is?
Or, if not, at least add a command line option to give the path to it?

### Describe alternatives you've considered

As said, currently i have to use the --skipImport, but it slows down the creation of the parts quite a bit, since i use a GUI for those tasks, which are much faster than command line commands.

I tried using the command lines but since i have depp folder paths, it takes much longer trough the command line compared to the GUI.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "ng g c with selection of app.module.ts" (#14434)

Issues.Title: Jasmine's clock mocks can't be used in library specs
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [ ] build - [ ] serve - [x] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Is this a regression? Not sure to be honest, but it works if the sample spec is part of the application in the workspace. ### Description Attempting to use Jasmine's clock mocks inside tests of CLI generated libraries throws an error saying 'Jasmine Clock was unable to install over custom global timer functions.'. It seems Jasmine is imported before Zone.js and therefore detects that the global timing functions, such as setTimeout, were changed afterwoods. The issue is similar to https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/11626. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction 

1. npm install --global @angular/cli.
2. ng new test-app
3. cd test-app
4. ng g library time-lib
5. ng test time-lib (passes)

6. Add the following test to a spec file inside the lib-1
 (e.g.: into "time-lib.service.spec.ts"):
 
 it('should install the clock mock', () => {
    jasmine.clock().install();
    jasmine.clock().uninstall();
  });

7. ng test time-lib (fails)
## üî• Exception or Error 

Chrome 74.0.3729 (Windows 10.0.0) TimeLibService should install the clock mock FAILED
        Error: Jasmine Clock was unable to install over custom global timer functions. Is the clock already installed?

            at ZoneDelegate.push.../../node_modules/zone.js/dist/zone.js.ZoneDelegate.invoke (C:/DEV/_test_projects/test-app/node_modules/zone.js/dist/zone.js:391:1)
            at ProxyZoneSpec.push.../../node_modules/zone.js/dist/zone-testing.js.ProxyZoneSpec.onInvoke (C:/DEV/_test_projects/test-app/node_modules/zone.js/dist/zone-testing.js:289:1)
            at ZoneDelegate.push.../../node_modules/zone.js/dist/zone.js.ZoneDelegate.invoke (C:/DEV/_test_projects/test-app/node_modules/zone.js/dist/zone.js:390:1)
            at Zone.push.../../node_modules/zone.js/dist/zone.js.Zone.run (C:/DEV/_test_projects/test-app/node_modules/zone.js/dist/zone.js:150:1)
            at runInTestZone (C:/DEV/_test_projects/test-app/node_modules/zone.js/dist/zone-testing.js:510:1)
            at UserContext. (C:/DEV/_test_projects/test-app/node_modules/zone.js/dist/zone-testing.js:525:1)

Issues.Title: Angular-cli does not compile vendor dependencies
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [x] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Is this a regression? Not sure. ### Description When doing `ng build` on a project that is using a dependency that's compiled with es6, the output contains es6 code which makes older browsers break. Issues.Title: [Datepicker] - Prevent autocomplete functionality
Issues.Body:
#### Please describe the feature you would like to request.
Add the option to prevent Datepicker from auto filling a date.

#### What is the use-case or motivation for this proposal?
Currently Datepicker does not autocomplete a date when 'Moment' considers the current input value as an invalid date. Since I need to change the business rule for the autocomplete feature (client requirement for years specifically), it would be great if I can stop the autofill in any case (not only when date is invalid) and create my own logic in a kind of middleware and send manually the new value I want to display.

#### Is there anything else we should know?
Current version:
    "@angular/material": "^7.3.4",
    "@angular/material-moment-adapter": "7.3.4",

Issues.Title: Docs site footer should link to full license
Issues.Body:
#### What is the expected behavior?
The applicable license shall match on all references to a specific piece of software.

#### What is the current behavior?
While on github it clearly states the repo is publicized under MIT-licence the website material.angular.io states the following:
Code licensed under an MIT-style License.

While the github repo has the full licence text by default, there is no link to the full licence text on the website. Stating that it is licenced under an MIT-**style** licence will create confusion about any potential change that could have been made to the agreement.

#### What are the steps to reproduce?
Trivial just visit: https://material.angular.io/ and scroll to the bottom

Issues.Title: build: remove example-module from gitignore
Issues.Body:
In order to work around an Angular Bazel bug where genfiles aren't
properly picked up in the `ng_module` metadata bundler, we need to
check-in the example module into the source-file and use the
example-module as a real source instead of generating it dynamically
through a genfile. This allows us to temporarily fix the examples package
until the bug (https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/30259) is fixed.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "build: remove example-module from gitignore" (#16040)

    at OverlayRef.attach (overlay.js:926)
    at MatMenuTrigger.openMenu (menu.js:1175)
    at MatMenuTrigger.toggleMenu (menu.js:1157)
    at MatMenuTrigger._handleClick (menu.js:1501)
    at MatMenuTrigger_click_HostBindingHandler (menu.js:1565)
    at executeListenerWithErrorHandling (core.js:16065)
    at wrapListenerIn_markDirtyAndPreventDefault (core.js:16100)
    at HTMLButtonElement.<anonymous> (platform-browser.js:1803)
```

#### What are the steps to reproduce?

1. `ng new myApp --enable-ivy`
2. `cd myApp`
3. `ng add @angular/material@next`
4. Import `MatMenuModule` in `app.module.ts`
5. Add the following to `app.component.html`
```
<button [matMenuTriggerFor]="menu">Menu</button>
<mat-menu #menu="matMenu">
  <button mat-menu-item>Item 1</button>
  <button mat-menu-item>Item 2</button>
</mat-menu>
``` 

#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?

I am using the latest release candidates of angular 8.  `ng version` yields the following:
```
Angular CLI: 8.0.0-rc.4
Node: 10.15.3
OS: win32 x64
Angular: 8.0.0-rc.4
... animations, cli, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... language-service, platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic
... router

Package                           Version
-----------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect         0.800.0-rc.4
@angular-devkit/build-angular     0.800.0-rc.4
@angular-devkit/build-optimizer   0.800.0-rc.4
@angular-devkit/build-webpack     0.800.0-rc.4
@angular-devkit/core              8.0.0-rc.4

@angular/cdk                      8.0.0-rc.1
@angular/material                 8.0.0-rc.1

@schematics/update                0.800.0-rc.4
rxjs                              6.4.0
typescript                        3.4.5

```
Browsers:
* Chrome: 73.0.3683.103 (Official Build) (64-bit)
* Edge: 44.17763.1.0
* Firefox 66.0.5 (64-bit)

#### Is there anything else we should know?
* It appears that the the portal for the menu isn't properly initialized (`menu.js:1175`).
* Everything functions without error when not opting into using ivy.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "MatMenu drop-down fails when ivy is enabled." (#16041)

Issues.Title: Mat form field input tag placeholder bug in Internet Explorer
Issues.Body:
#### Bug, feature request, or proposal:
Mat form field input tag placeholder bug in Internet Explorer

#### What is the expected behavior?
Using the form field without getting in a state where you cannot type in the input field

#### What is the current behavior?
When clicking on the placeholder in top of the form field after focusing on the form field you are not able to type in the input field

#### What are the steps to reproduce?
HTML code which provides the bug:
![HTML input field not working](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/50622252/57699049-4eee8e80-7657-11e9-809d-4138f5302614.PNG)
The behavior can be tried on https://material.angular.io/components/form-field/overview
A work around is the following HTML code:
![HTML input field working](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/50622252/57699081-63cb2200-7657-11e9-8362-14cf169b3623.PNG)

#### What is the use-case or motivation for changing an existing behavior?
The code getting around the problem will be deprecated in later versions so it is necessary to get this bug fixed. Info about the deprecation can be found on https://material.angular.io/components/form-field/overview

#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?
Angular: 7.2.3
Material: 7.3.1
OS: Windows 7 Enterprise - Service Pack 1
TypeScript: 3.1.6
Browsers affected: Internet Explorer
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Mat form field input tag placeholder bug in Internet Explorer" (#16026)

Issues.Title: Add a mat-menu-group so that we can open (new) and close (old) menus on a single click.
Issues.Body:
#### Please describe the feature you would like to request.
Similar has been asked [HERE](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/48467009/how-to-open-mat-menu-on-a-single-click-and-close-other-opened-menu-if-there-is-a):

For the same reason we have `mat-accordion` wrapping `expansion-panel` we need `mat-menu-group` wrapping `mat-menu-trigger`.

Currently we have to click 2 times when a menu is already open and we want to open  a new one. This feels unnatural to me.

A wrapping instance could control the closing and opening of its menu children.

1. [JQUERY EXAMPLE](http://jsfiddle.net/jvmnrg2x/) (desired behaviour)
2. [CURRENT MAT-MENU](https://stackblitz.com/angular/dkreoalaala?file=app%2Fmenu-position-example.ts) (no fluid skimming possible.)

#### What is the use-case or motivation for this proposal?

Definitely this would provide a better and more fluid UX if we can skim through the menus inside of a `mat-menu-group`. I like the idea of the backdrop that should still be there OUTSIDE of the `mat-menu-group`.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Add a mat-menu-group so that we can open (new) and close (old) menus on a single click." (#16036)

Issues.Title: Bring back for easy spacing in mat-card-actions, mat-dialog-actions, mat-toolbar etc

Issues.Title: Toolbar modes
Issues.Body:
#### Please describe the feature you would like to request.
A multi-mode toolbar that implements a contextual overlay 

#### What is the use-case or motivation for this proposal?

I am working on a PWA, intended to work on both desktop and mobile and now is the question how to properly implement a contextual toolbar since I want to have basically a search-bar like on the MDC webpage (https://material.io/develop/web/). 

Of course it could be done quite easily by just using structural directives and manipulating the child-content directly but if the toolbar is used in a layout frame with router then services would be required. I was thinking about to implement the context (search bar) similar to a bottom sheet such that get a contextRef programatically as handle. 

Actually my question is: how would the angular material team solve this? or do you think there is no generic solution so you just keep it to the minimum (the current state)?

My current implementation does not have any context yet only a cdk portal service to change page-actions. 

The more I think about it the less it makes sense to have a app bar defined in a layout (at least if you want to change the title, possible contexts and page actions you dont have really code-reduction) 

#### Is there anything else we should know?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Toolbar modes" (#16030)

Issues.Title: Add a way to better identify clicked elements
Issues.Body: #### Please describe the feature you would like to request. Add a way to identify the element that has been clicked #### What is the use-case or motivation for this proposal? Currently we are using Sentry for error reporting. In the breadcrumbs this is what we see: `div.mat-form-field-wrapper > div.mat-form-field-flex` This does not really provide us with any good info about what element was clicked. Perhaps we also could have some more into about the element's context?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Add a way to better identify clicked elements" (#16031)

Issues.Title: drag and drop bug with layout gap
Issues.Body:
# Bug Report

#### What is the expected behavior?
That the layout applies correctly, as it does when there is not a cdkDragPlaceHolder in it.

#### What is the current behavior?
When you drag an element sometimes the layout is not applied correctly, the elements are not in the expected way. Some of them, usually the drag placeholder, are in a wrong position.

#### What are the steps to reproduce?

https://stackblitz.com/github/santiagoilli/angular-flex-layout-gap-drag-drop-issue

Take some of the right drag elements, and drag those into the left container. When you have moved a few, add one more and move it in the slot left container, you will now see how one o two of them are not in the expected position, probably the dragPlaceHolder is one of them (the one with opacity).

#### What is the use-case or motivation for changing an existing behavior?
I need to make a puzzle effect, so the layoutGap would be very usefull.

#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?
"@angular/core": "~7.2.15"
"@angular/cdk": "^7.3.7"
"@angular/flex-layout": "^7.0.0-beta.24"
 "@angular/material": "^7.3.7"
"typescript": "~3.2.2"
Google Chrome Versi√≥n 74.0.3729.131 (Build oficial) (64 bits)
Windows 10 Pro 64 bits

#### Is there anything else we should know?
Sometimes the behaviour is as expected, so try to move a few of the elements and then take one from the right and move around the left container.

Issues.Title: Material Tabs should use `<a>` tag instead of `div` to improve websites SEO
Issues.Body:
#### Please describe the feature you would like to request.
Currently the tab is using `div` tags instead of `a` tag. Google webmaster team recently uploaded video series on JavaScript SEO, and in [this video ](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nwGY-9lwTF4&list=PLKoqnv2vTMUPOalM1zuWDP9OQl851WMM9&index=4 )he says:

> Make sure to include useful link anchorText and use the HTML anchor tag (...) do not rely on other HTML elements.


#### What is the use-case or motivation for this proposal?
Improve users wbsites SEO performance
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Material Tabs should use `<a>` tag instead of `div` to improve websites SEO " (#16025)
